At the request of the Township of Maplewood, Keller and Kirkpatrick performed a
preliminary multi-way stop needs analysis in accordance with Section 2B of the
MUTCD for the unsignalized intersection of Ridgewood Road and Cedar Lane/E.
Cedar Lane. The result of the multi-way stop analysis is that the installation of a
four-way stop is not warranted at the intersection of Ridgewood Road and Cedar
Lane/E. Cedar Lane. A copy of the preliminary multi-way stop analysis for this
intersection can be found in Appendix I.
Crash Analysis: Keller and Kirkpatrick obtained the individual crash reports for
the three-year period extending from January 1, 2004 through to August 30, 2006
from the Township of Maplewood and prepared collision diagrams summarizing
the crashes for each year at this intersection. According to the individual crash
reports zero, two and two crashes occurred at the intersection of Ridgewood
Road and Cedar Lane/E. Cedar Lane during the years of 2004, 2005 and 2006,
respectively. In addition, both crashes that occurred in 2005 and 2006 were
angle type crashes. Upon review of the individual crash reports, it is evident that
all but one of the angle type crashes was a result of poor intersection sight
distance along Ridgewood Road.
Conceptual Solution: The following lists the recommended improvements to the
intersection of Ridgewood Road and Cedar Lane/E. Cedar Lane to address the
need for traffic calming measures and/or traffic safety improvements as identified
in the traffic survey for this intersection. Input received at the February 22, 2007
field meeting with the Maplewood Township Engineer was incorporated, where
appropriate, in the recommended improvements.
¾ Install bump-outs in the northeast and southeast quadrants. The bump-outs
will increase intersection sight distance, increase visibility for and of the
pedestrian, and may reduce travel speeds along Ridgewood Road.
¾ Clear the sight triangles, as specified in both AASHTO and the Maplewood
Township Zoning and Development Regulations, of all obstructions, as
reasonable.
¾ Eliminate on-street parking along Ridgewood Road northbound within the
limits of the sight triangles.
¾ Widen the existing sidewalk in front of the local businesses located along
Ridgewood Road northbound, north of Cedar Lane to discourage parking.
Additional options include the installation of speed cushions or chicanes along
Ridgewood Road south of Cedar Lane/E. Cedar Lane.
The estimated construction cost for the conceptual solution, without the speed
cushions or chicanes, is $12,300, which does not include any costs associated

text.b: Traffic Calming Needs Study – Township of Maplewood, Essex County

page.text: August 2007
with the acquisition of right of way, potential drainage modifications or utility
impacts. A copy of the construction cost estimate can be found in Appendix E.
A plan copy of the conceptual solution for this intersection can be found in
Appendix F.
1. Ridgewood Road: The traffic survey identified speeding, limited intersection
sight distance at unspecified locations, and significant pedestrian traffic as
hazards along this roadway.
Existing Conditions: Ridgewood Road within the Township of Maplewood is an
undivided two-lane urban collector running south to north with an approximate
average roadway width of 30 feet. It has an approximate overall length of 1.3
miles within the Township with numerous unsignalized intersections and a
flashing signal at Baker Street. According to the NJDOT Straight-Line Diagram
for Ridgewood Road, the municipal boundary between Maplewood Township and
Millburn Township is located approximately 50 feet south of Bailey Road and the
municipal boundary between Maplewood Township and South Orange Township
is located approximately 150 feet north of Cedar Lane/E. Cedar Lane.
Ridgewood Road has a posted speed limit of 25 mph and is under the jurisdiction
of Maplewood Township.
According to Maplewood Township ordinance, no vehicle shall be parked on any
thoroughfare or public parking lot between the hours of 2:00 A.M. and 6:00 A.M.
Parking is prohibited at all times along Ridgewood Road southbound from the
municipality boundary between Maplewood Township and South Orange
Township to New England Road. Parking is also prohibited along Ridgewood
Road northbound from Curtis Place to Lenox Place and from Woodland Road to
a point 45 feet south. Stopping and standing is prohibited along Ridgewood
Road southbound from the municipal boundary between Maplewood Township
and South Orange Township to Durand Road, and along Ridgewood Road
northbound from Maryland Road to Virginia Road and from Woodland Avenue to
a point 82 feet north thereof.
The land use along Ridgewood Road is basically residential with a few small
business located in the vicinity of Cedar Lane/E. Cedar Lane. The majority of the
residences and businesses within the project area have off-street parking. In
addition, Jefferson Elementary School is located along Ridgewood Road at its
intersection with Virginia Road.
Conceptual Solutions: The following summarizes two conceptual solutions
which address the need for traffic calming measures and/or traffic safety
improvements as identified in the traffic survey for Ridgewood Road. Input

text.b: Traffic Calming Needs Study – Township of Maplewood, Essex County

page.text: August 2007
received at the February 22, 2007 field meeting with the Maplewood Township
Engineer was incorporated, where appropriate, in the recommended
improvements.
¾ Install bump-outs at the following intersecting roadways with Ridgewood
Road.
The bump-outs will increase intersection sight distance, increase visibility for
and of the pedestrian, and may reduce travel speeds along Ridgewood Road.
¾ Provide “ladder” striping within each crosswalk so as to increase their visibility
to motorists.
¾ Clear the sight triangles, as specified in both AASHTO and the Maplewood
Township Zoning and Development Regulations, of all obstructions, as
reasonable, for each intersection along Ridgewood Road.
If the bump-outs do not achieve the desired result with respect to reducing travel
speeds along Ridgewood Road over a predetermined time frame then speed
cushions could be installed in areas identified with excessive speeding.
The estimated construction cost for Conceptual Solution No. 1 is $352,000,
which does not include any costs associated with the acquisition of right of way,
potential drainage modifications or utility impacts. A copy of the construction cost
estimate can be found in Appendix E.
¾ Install raised intersections at the following intersecting roadways with
Ridgewood Road.

text.b: Traffic Calming Needs Study – Township of Maplewood, Essex County

page.text: August 2007
The raised intersections will increase visibility for and of the pedestrian and
will reduce travel speeds along Ridgewood Road. However, they do not
address the concerns regarding limited intersection sight distance.
¾ Provide “ladder” striping within each crosswalk and clear the sight triangles as
recommended in Conceptual Solution No. 1.
The estimated construction cost for Conceptual Solution No. 2 is $132,000,
which does not include any costs associated with the acquisition of right of way,
potential drainage modifications or utility impacts. A copy of the construction cost
estimate can be found in Appendix E.
The following traffic calming measures were deemed inappropriate for this
roadway as noted:
¾ On-Street Parking or a Bicycle Lane, both of which are a form of roadway
narrowing, provide a perception of enclosure to the motorist, and in turn
reduce speed. However, since off-street parking is readily available the
demand for on-street parking may not be adequate to provide a constant
stimulus. The striping for the parking stalls and/or a bicycle lane alone will not
provide adequate stimuli to significantly treduce travel speeds.
¾ Chicanes were deemed inappropriate due to the close proximity of the side
streets with one another.
¾ Center Islands would restrict access to and from driveways from one
direction. In addition, currently available on-street parking would be
eliminated and thereby result in a net increase in travel speeds.
¾ Traffic Circles were deemed inappropriate due to the close proximity of
intersecting side streets at various locations along Ridgewood Road and
since they would most likely require the relocation of existing crosswalks to
locations with lower driver expectancy.
Conceptual Solution No. 1 is our recommended alternative since it addresses
each of the issues identified in the traffic survey.

text.b: Traffic Calming Needs Study – Township of Maplewood, Essex County

page.text: August 2007
2. Boyden Avenue: The traffic survey identified speeding as a hazard along this
roadway.
Existing Conditions: Boyden Avenue within the Township of Maplewood is an
undivided two-lane urban collector running south to north with an approximate
roadway width of 29 feet. It has an approximate overall length of 1.5 miles within
the Township with numerous unsignalized intersections and five signalized
intersections at Irvington Avenue, Parker Avenue, Elmwood Avenue, Springfield
Avenue, and Stuyvesant Avenue. According to the NJDOT Straight-Line
Diagram for Boyden Avenue, the roadway extends from C.R. 619, Stuyvesant
Avenue/40
th
Street to C.R. 665, Irvington Avenue within the Township of
Maplewood. Boyden Avenue has a posted speed limit of 25 mph and is under
the jurisdiction of Maplewood Township.
Parking is prohibited at all times along Boyden Avenue northbound from a point
105 feet south of Parker Avenue to Orchard Road and from Springfield Avenue
to a point 188 feet south thereof. Parking is prohibited along Boyden Avenue
southbound from Springfield Avenue to Elmwood Avenue and from Springfield
Avenue to a point 200 feet north-east thereof. Parking is also prohibited along
Boyden Avenue southbound from Irvington Avenue to a point 75 feet south
thereof. Parking is prohibited along Boyden Avenue northbound from Springfield
Avenue to a point 230 feet south thereof, from a point 594 feet south of
Springfield Avenue to the dividing line between Maplewood Township and the
Town of Irvington and from Springfield Avenue to the dividing line between the
Township of Maplewood and the Town of Irvington. Stopping or standing is
prohibited at all times along both sides of Boyden Avenue from a point 170 feet
north of Elmwood Avenue to Orchard Road and from Parker Avenue to a point
155 feet north thereof. Stopping or standing is also prohibited along Boyden
Avenue northbound from Irvington Avenue to a point 205 feet south thereof, from
a point 40 feet south of Meadowbrook Place North to Elmwood Avenue and from
Parker Avenue to a point 105 feet south; and along Boyden Avenue southbound
from Elmwood Avenue to a point 170 feet north of Elmwood Avenue, from
Irvington Avenue to a point 195 feet south thereof and from Parker Avenue to a
point 115 feet south thereof. Stopping or standing is prohibited along Boyden
Avenue southbound from Boyden Parkway to Elmwood Avenue. No stopping or
standing is permitted along Boyden Avenue northbound from Harding Street to a
point 100 feet south of Jacoby Street and from a point 230 feet south of
Springfield Avenue to a point 364 feet south thereof; and along Boyden Avenue
southbound from Jacoby Street to Menzel Avenue.
Stopping or standing is prohibited on the north side of Boyden Avenue beginning
at a point formed by the intersection of the tangent extended of the north curbline
of Elmwood Avenue and the west curbline of Boyden Avenue a distance of 100
feet to the starting point of the no-parking zone; thence south along the curbline
of Boyden Avenue and on a curve to the right along Elmwood Avenue for a
distance of 150 feet. Stopping or standing is also prohibited on the north side of

text.b: Traffic Calming Needs Study – Township of Maplewood, Essex County

page.text: August 2007
Boyden Avenue beginning at a point formed by the intersection of the tangent
extended of the north curbline of Orchard Road and the east curbline of Boyden
Avenue thence north-east along the tangent of Orchard Road a distance of 80
feet to the starting point of the no-parking zone; thence west along the curbline of
Orchard (Orange) Road and on a curve to the right along Boyden Avenue for a
distance of 300 feet. Parking is permitted along Boyden Avenue northbound for
a time period of three hours from 8:00 A.M. to 4:00 P.M. everyday from Boyden
Avenue to a point 300 feet west thereof and along Boyden Avenue southbound
from Elmwood Avenue to Midland Boulevard.
The land use along Boyden Avenue is basically residential north of Elmwood
Avenue. South of Elmwood Avenue, the land use along Boyden Avenue is
basically commercial and residential. The majority of the single-family
residences within the project area have off-street parking. In addition, the Seth
Boyden Elementary School is located along Boyden Avenue approximately 400
feet south of Springfield Avenue. A Maplewood Township firehouse is located
along Boyden Avenue at the intersection of Springfield Avenue and the
Maplewood Township Volunteer First Aid Squad is also located along Boyden
Avenue near Elmwood Avenue. The Maplewood Community Pool is located
along Boyden Avenue between Springfield Avenue and Meadowbrook Place.
Conceptual Solutions: The following summarizes two conceptual solutions
which address the need for traffic calming measures and/or traffic safety
improvements as identified in the traffic survey for Boyden Avenue. Input
received at the February 22, 2007 field meeting with the Maplewood Township
Engineer was incorporated, where appropriate, in the recommended
improvements.
Conceptual Solution No. 1: While only excessive speeding was identified as a
hazard along Boyden Avenue, numerous pedestrian crossings exist along
Boyden Avenue within the project limits and Conceptual Solution No. 1 reflects
this fact.
¾ Install bump-outs at the following intersecting roadways with Boyden Avenue.
The bump-outs will increase intersection sight distance, increase visibility for
and of the pedestrian, and may reduce travel speeds along Boyden Avenue.

text.b: Traffic Calming Needs Study – Township of Maplewood, Essex County

page.text: August 2007
¾ Provide “ladder” striping within each crosswalk so as to increase their visibility
to motorists.
If the bump-outs do not achieve the desired result with respect to reducing travel
speeds along Boyden Avenue over a predetermined time frame then speed
cushions could be installed in areas identified with excessive speeding.
The estimated construction cost for the Conceptual Solution No. 1 is $77,000,
which does not include any costs associated with right of way acquisition or utility
impacts. A copy of the construction cost estimate can be found in Appendix E.
¾ Install raised intersections at the following intersecting roadways with Boyden
Avenue.
The raised intersections will increase visibility for and of the pedestrian and
will reduce travel speeds along Boyden Avenue.
¾ Provide “ladder” striping within each crosswalk as recommended in
Conceptual Solution No. 1.
Additional options include the installation of speed cushions along Boyden
Avenue between Springfield Avenue and Elmwood Avenue.
The estimated construction cost for the Conceptual Solution No. 2, without the
speed cushions, is $84,000, which does not include any costs associated with
right of way acquisition or utility impacts. A copy of the construction cost
estimate can be found in Appendix E.
In addition to Conceptual Solution Nos. 1 and 2, it was agreed at the February
22, 2007 field meeting that extension track striping should be installed at the
signalized intersection of Boyden Avenue and Elmwood Avenue to direct
motorists through the intersection.
The following traffic calming measures were deemed inappropriate for this
roadway as noted:
¾ On-Street Parking or a Bicycle Lane, both of which are a form of roadway
narrowing, provide a perception of enclosure to the motorist, and in turn

text.b: Traffic Calming Needs Study – Township of Maplewood, Essex County

page.text: August 2007
reduce speed. However, since off-street parking is readily available the
demand for on-street parking may not be adequate to provide a constant
stimulus. The striping for the parking stalls and/or a bicycle lane alone will not
provide adequate stimuli to significantly reduce travel speeds.
¾ Chicanes were deemed inappropriate due to the close proximity of the side
streets with one another and the existing non-tangential horizontal alignment.
¾ Center Islands would restrict access to and from driveways from one
direction. In addition, currently available on-street parking would be
eliminated and thereby result in a net increase in travel speeds.
¾ Traffic Circles were deemed inappropriate since they would most likely
require the relocation of existing crosswalks to locations with lower driver
expectancy. In addition, traffic circles would most likely require modifications
to the existing curblines, which may require additional right-of-way and would
impact the residences in the vicinity of the intersections.
Conceptual Solution No. 1 is our recommended alternative since it addresses the
issue of excessive speeding as identified in the traffic survey and increases
pedestrian safety.
3. Prospect Street: The traffic survey identified speeding as a hazard along this
roadway.
Existing Conditions: Prospect Street within the Township of Maplewood is an
undivided two-lane urban collector running west to east with an approximate
roadway width of 36 feet. The studied limits extend along Prospect Street
between Springfield Avenue and the municipal boundary between Maplewood
Township and South Orange Township. Prospect Street has a posted speed
limit of 25 mph and is under the jurisdiction of Maplewood Township. All of the
intersections along Prospect Street are unsignalized with the exception of
Springfield Avenue, Tuscan Road and Parker Avenue which are signalized. A
flashing signal is located at the intersection of Prospect Street and Harvard
Avenue.
According to Maplewood Township ordinance, no vehicle shall be parked on any
thoroughfare or public parking lot between the hours of 2:00 A.M. and 6:00 A.M.
Parking is prohibited at all times along Prospect Street northbound from Harvard
Avenue to a point 100 feet north of Harvard Avenue and to a point 145 feet south
of Harvard Avenue; and along Prospect Street southbound from Harvard Avenue
to a point 110 feet north of Harvard Avenue and to a point 110 feet south of
Harvard Avenue.
Stopping and standing is prohibited at all times along Prospect
Street northbound from Parker Avenue to a point 140 feet north thereof, from
Parker Avenue to a point 285 feet south thereof and along Prospect Street
southbound from Parker Avenue to a point 155 feet south thereof. Stopping and
standing is also prohibited along Prospect Street northbound from Springfield
Avenue to a point 50 feet north thereof and along Prospect Street southbound

text.b: Traffic Calming Needs Study – Township of Maplewood, Essex County

page.text: August 2007
from a point 160 feet north of Springfield Avenue to a point 70 feet north thereof
and from Springfield Avenue to a point 80 feet north thereof. No stopping or
standing is permitted along Prospect Street northbound from Tuscan Road to a
point 160 feet north thereof and from Tuscan Road to a point 105 feet south
thereof
Parking is restricted to a time period of two hours along Prospect Street
northbound between 8:00 A.M. and 4:00 P.M. on school days from Elmwood
Avenue to a point 120 feet south of Parker Avenue, from Oakland Road to a
point 120 feet south of Elmwood Avenue and from a point 140 feet north of
Parker Avenue to the South Orange-Maplewood line. Parking is restricted to a
time period of one hour along Prospect Street northbound between 9:00 A.M.
and 7:00 P.M. everyday from a point 50 feet north of Springfield Avenue to a
point 50 feet north thereof. Parking is restricted to a time period of two hours
along Prospect Street southbound between 8:00 A.M. and 4:00 P.M. on school
days from Beach Street to a point 120 feet north of Parker Avenue, from Franklin
Place to a point 120 feet north of Oakland Road, from a point 155 feet south of
Parker Avenue to a point 120 feet north of Franklin Place and from the South
Orange-Maplewood line to a point 120 feet north of Beach Street. Parking is
restricted to a time period of one hour along Prospect Street southbound
between 9:00 A.M. and 7:00 P.M. everyday from a point 80 feet north of
Springfield Avenue to a point 20 feet north thereof.
The land use along Prospect Street within the project limits is basically residential
with the majority of the residences having off-street parking.
Conceptual Solutions: The following summarizes three conceptual solutions
which address the need for traffic calming measures and/or traffic safety
improvements as identified in the traffic survey for Prospect Street. Input
received at the February 22, 2007 field meeting with the Maplewood Township
Engineer was incorporated, where appropriate, in the recommended
improvements.
Conceptual Solution No. 1: While only excessive speeding was identified as a
hazard along Prospect Street, numerous pedestrian crossings exist along
Prospect Street within the project limits and Conceptual Solution No. 1 reflects
this fact.
¾ Install bump-outs at the following intersecting roadways with Prospect Street.

text.b: Traffic Calming Needs Study – Township of Maplewood, Essex County

page.text: August 2007
The bump-outs will increase intersection sight distance, increase visibility for
and of the pedestrian, and may reduce travel speeds along Prospect Street.
¾ Provide “ladder” striping within each crosswalk so as to increase their visibility
to motorists.
¾ Install chicanes between the intersections of Tuscan Road and Harvard
Avenue and between Jennifer Lane and Franklin Place.
The estimated construction cost for Conceptual Solution No. 1 is $189,000,
which does not include any costs associated with the acquisition of right of way,
potential drainage modifications or utility impacts. A copy of the construction cost
estimate can be found in Appendix E.
¾ Install raised intersections at the following intersecting roadways with
Prospect Street.
The raised intersections will increase visibility for and of the pedestrian and
will reduce travel speeds along Prospect Street.
¾ Provide “ladder” striping within each crosswalk as recommended in
Conceptual Solution No. 1.
The estimated construction cost for Conceptual Solution No. 2 is $78,000, which
does not include any costs associated with the acquisition of right of way,
potential drainage modifications or utility impacts. A copy of the construction cost
estimate can be found in Appendix E.
Conceptual Solution No. 3 proposes to reduce speeds along Prospect Street
within the project limits by narrowing the roadway with a center island, essentially
creating a boulevard effect. The roadway width would be narrowed to provide a
12-foot wide travel lane on either side of the center island, as shown in Figure 6.
The center island will reduce travel speeds along Prospect Street and provide a
refuge for pedestrians crossing the street. In addition, “ladder” striping within
each crosswalk should be provided as recommended in Conceptual Solution No.
1. It was assumed that the pavement design for Prospect Street was continuous
for the cross section of roadway. The quality of the drainage system along
Prospect Street will also need to be evaluated since the travel lanes would be
shifted closer to the curbline.

text.b: Traffic Calming Needs Study – Township of Maplewood, Essex County

page.text: August 2007
The estimated construction cost for Conceptual Solution No. 3 is $422,000,
which does not include any costs associated with the acquisition of right of way,
potential drainage modifications or utility impacts. A copy of the construction cost
estimate can be found in Appendix E.
The following traffic calming measures were deemed inappropriate for this
roadway as noted:
¾ On-Street Parking or a Bicycle Lane, both of which are a form of roadway
narrowing, provide a perception of enclosure to the motorist, and in turn
reduce speed. However, since off-street parking is readily available the
demand for on-street parking may not be adequate to provide a constant
stimulus. The striping for the parking stalls and/or a bicycle lane alone will not
provide adequate stimuli to significantly reduce travel speeds.
¾ Traffic Circles were deemed inappropriate since they would most likely
require the relocation of existing crosswalks to locations with lower driver
expectancy.
Conceptual Solution No. 1 is our recommended alternative since it addresses the
issue of excessive speeding as identified in the traffic survey and increases
pedestrian safety.
4. Baker Street: The traffic survey identified speeding, limited visibility resulting
from the overpass and significant pedestrian traffic as hazards along this
roadway.
Existing Conditions: Baker Street is an undivided two-lane local road running
east to west with an approximate roadway width of 40 feet. It has an
approximate overall length of 0.5 miles with four unsignalized intersections and a
traffic signal at the intersection of Baker Street and Valley Street. The studied
limits extend along Baker Street between Valley Street and Maplewood Avenue.
Baker Street has a posted speed limit of 25 mph and is under the jurisdiction of
Maplewood Township.
According to Maplewood Township ordinance, no vehicle shall be parked on any
thoroughfare or public parking lot between the hours of 2:00 A.M. and 6:00 A.M.
Parking is prohibited at all times along Baker Street westbound from Valley
Street to a point 270 feet west thereof. Parking is prohibited at all times along
Baker Street eastbound from Valley Street to a point 250 feet west thereof and
from the Erie-Lackawanna Railroad to Maplewood Avenue. Parking along Baker
Street westbound is restricted to a time period of one hour between 9:00 A.M.
and 7:00 P.M. everyday from the Erie-Lackawanna Railroad to Maplewood
Avenue. Parking along Baker Street westbound is restricted to a time period of
thirty minutes at all times from Burnet Street to a point 190 feet northwest
thereof. Parking along Baker Street eastbound is restricted to a time period of

text.b: Traffic Calming Needs Study – Township of Maplewood, Essex County

page.text: August 2007
three hours between 8:00 A.M. and 4:00 P.M. everyday from Burnet Street to a
point 255 feet west thereof. Parking along Baker Street westbound is restricted
to a time period of fifteen minutes at all times from Dunnell Road to a point 160
feet east thereof.
The land use along Baker Street is basically recreational. Memorial Park and the
Maplewood Country Club are located along Baker Street as well as Maplewood
Middle School and the Maplewood Memorial Library.
Conceptual Solutions: The following summarizes the conceptual solution which
addresses the need for traffic calming measures and/or traffic safety
improvements as identified in the traffic survey for Baker Street. Input received
at the February 22, 2007 field meeting with the Maplewood Township Engineer
was incorporated, where appropriate, in the recommended improvements.
The conceptual solution proposes to reduce speeding and improve pedestrian
safety by installing a bump-out at the intersection of Baker Street and Burnett
Street. Mid-block narrowing would be installed along Baker Street in the vicinity
of Dunnell Road. The bump-out and mid-block narrowing would reduce the
crossing time for pedestrians while improving their visibility to motorists. In
addition, it is recommended that the pedestrian crosswalks include “ladder”
striping to increase their visibility to motorists. It is also recommended that a
speed study be performed along Baker Street to determine the effectiveness of
speed cushions.
The estimated construction cost for the Conceptual Solution is $23,000, which
does not include any costs associated with right of way acquisition or utility
impacts. A copy of the construction cost estimate can be found in Appendix E.
The following traffic calming measures were deemed inappropriate for this
roadway as noted:
¾ Chicanes were deemed inappropriate due to the existing non-tangential
horizontal alignment along Baker Street.
¾ Center Islands would restrict access to and from driveways from one
direction. In addition, currently available on-street parking would be
eliminated and thereby result in a net increase in travel speeds.
¾ Traffic Circles were deemed inappropriate since they would most likely
require the relocation of existing crosswalks to locations with lower driver
expectancy and would eliminate much of the existing on-street parking along
Baker Street.
5. Jacoby Street: The traffic study indicated that some motorists utilize Jacoby
Street as a bypass route between Springfield Avenue and Boyden Avenue.
Speeding and limited sight distance has also been noted as a hazard along this

text.b: Traffic Calming Needs Study – Township of Maplewood, Essex County

page.text: August 2007
roadway. It was also noted during the field meeting that 44
th
street is also used
as a bypass route to get to Chancellor Avenue.
Existing Conditions: Jacoby Street is an undivided two-lane local road running
south to north with an approximate roadway width of 29 feet. The studied limits
extend along Jacoby Street between Boyden Avenue and Springfield Avenue.
Jacoby Street has a posted speed limit of 25 mph and is under the jurisdiction of
Maplewood Township. 44
th
Street is an undivided two-lane local road running
east to west with an approximate roadway width of 30 feet and extends from
Jacoby Street to Chancellor Avenue.
According to Maplewood Township ordinance, no vehicle shall be parked on any
thoroughfare or public parking lot between the hours of 2:00 A.M. and 6:00 A.M.
Stopping and standing is prohibited along Jacoby Street northbound from a point
150 feet north of Boyden Avenue to a point 150 feet south of Boyden Avenue.
Stopping and standing is prohibited along Jacoby Street southbound from
Springfield Avenue to a point 150 feet south thereof. Parking along Jacoby Street
is restricted to a time period of two hours between 9:00 A.M. and 6:00 P.M.
everyday except Sunday from Springfield Avenue to a point 200 feet south
thereof. Parking along Jacoby Street is restricted to a time period of three hours
between 8:00 A.M. and 4:00 P.M. everyday from Springfield Avenue to 44
th
Street. Parking is prohibited at all times along 44
th
Street eastbound from Jacoby
Street to Chancellor Avenue. Parking along 44
th
Street westbound is restricted to
a time period of three hours between 8:00 A.M. and 4:00 P.M. everyday from
Jacoby Street to Chancellor Avenue.
The land use along Jacoby Street is basically residential and commercial. The
land use along 44
th
Street is basically residential. The majority of the single-
family residences within the project area have off-street parking.
Conceptual Solutions: The following summarizes the conceptual solution which
addresses the need for traffic calming measures and/or traffic safety
improvements as identified in the traffic survey for Jacoby Street. Input received
at the February 22, 2007 field meeting with the Maplewood Township Engineer
was incorporated, where appropriate, in the recommended improvements.
¾ Convert 44
th
Street into a one-way street towards Chancellor Avenue to
reduce the amount of cut-through traffic along this roadway and Jacoby
Street.
¾ Construct a concrete center island along Springfield Avenue at Jacoby Street
to create a right-in, right-out only operation. This will further reduce the
number of motorists utilizing this roadway as a bypass.
The estimated construction cost for the Conceptual Solution is $32,000, which
does not include any costs associated with right of way acquisition or utility
impacts. A copy of the construction cost estimate can be found in Appendix E.

text.b: Traffic Calming Needs Study – Township of Maplewood, Essex County

page.text: August 2007
The following traffic calming measures were deemed inappropriate for this
roadway as noted:
¾ On-Street Parking or a Bicycle Lane, both of which are a form of roadway
narrowing, provide a perception of enclosure to the motorist, and in turn
reduce speed. However, since on-street parking is readily available the
demand for on-street parking may not be adequate to provide a constant
stimulus. The striping for the parking stalls and/or a bicycle lane alone will not
provide adequate stimuli to significantly reduce travel speeds.
¾ Chicanes were deemed inappropriate due to the close proximity of the
residential driveways with one another and the short length of roadway
studied.
¾ Center Islands would restrict access to and from driveways from one
direction. In addition, currently available on-street parking would be
eliminated and thereby result in a net increase in travel speeds.
¾ Traffic Circles were deemed inappropriate since they would most likely
require modifications to the existing curblines, which may require additional
right-of-way and would impact the residences in the vicinity of the
intersections.

text.b: 1. Sommer Avenue including Hubert Place, Osborne Terrace and Girard

page.text: Place: The traffic survey identified this collection of roadways for speeding and
as a bypass route between Valley Street and Prospect Street/Springfield Avenue.
Existing Conditions: Sommer
Avenue, Hubert Place,
Osborne Terrace and Girard
Place are all undivided two-
lane local roads with
approximate roadway widths of
29 feet. All roadways have a
posted speed limit of 25 mph
and are under the jurisdiction
of Maplewood Township.
According to Maplewood
Township ordinance, no
vehicle shall be parked on any
thoroughfare or public parking
lot between the hours of 2:00
A.M. and 6:00 A.M. No other parking restrictions exist in the ordinance for
Sommer Avenue, Hubert Place, Osborne Terrace or Girard Place.

text.b: Traffic Calming Needs Study – Township of Maplewood, Essex County

page.text: August 2007
The land use along Sommer Avenue, Hubert Place, Osborne Terrace and Girard
Place is basically residential. The majority of the single-family residences within
the project area have off-street parking. Tuscan Elementary School is located
along Harvard Avenue between Valley Street and Osborne Terrace, which is
immediately north of this collection of roadways.
Conceptual Solutions: The following summarizes two conceptual solutions
which addresses the need for traffic calming measures and/or traffic safety
improvements as identified in the traffic survey for Sommer Avenue. Input
received at the February 22, 2007 field meeting with the Maplewood Township
Engineer was incorporated, where appropriate, in the recommended
improvements.
Conceptual Solution No. 1 proposes to construct traffic circles along Sommer
Avenue at its intersections with Hubert Place and Osborne Terrace and speed
cushions along Girard Place between Valley Street and Hubert Place and Hubert
Place and Osborne Terrace. This would reduce speeding and deter vehicles
from using these roadways as bypasses since vehicles would be forced to slow
down along each roadway. The traffic circles would include pavers or other
treatment to create a mountable curb for larger vehicles.
The estimated construction cost for the Conceptual Solution No. 1 is $32,000,
which does not include any costs associated with right of way acquisition or utility
impacts. A copy of the construction cost estimate can be found in Appendix E.
¾ Install raised intersections at the following locations:
The raised intersections will increase visibility for and of the pedestrian, reduce
travel speeds, and may deter motorists from using this collection of roadways as
a bypass.
The estimated construction cost for the Conceptual Solution No. 2 is $54,000,
which does not include any costs associated with right of way acquisition or utility
impacts. A copy of the construction cost estimate can be found in Appendix E.
The following traffic calming measures were deemed inappropriate for this
roadway as noted:

text.b: Traffic Calming Needs Study – Township of Maplewood, Essex County

page.text: August 2007
¾ On-Street Parking or a Bicycle Lane, both of which are a form of roadway
narrowing, provide a perception of enclosure to the motorist, and in turn
reduce speed. However, since off-street parking is readily available the
demand for on-street parking may not be adequate to provide a constant
stimulus. The striping for the parking stalls and/or a bicycle lane alone will not
provide adequate stimuli to significantly reduce travel speeds or deter
motorists from using this collection of roadways as a bypass route.
¾ Chicanes were deemed inappropriate due to the close proximity of the
driveways.
¾ Center Islands would restrict access to and from driveways from one
direction. In addition, currently available on-street parking would be
eliminated and thereby result in a net increase in travel speeds.
Conceptual Solution No. 1 is our recommended alternative since it addresses the
issue of excessive speeding and bypass traffic as identified in the traffic survey.
2. Kensington Terrace: The traffic study identified speeding as a hazard along
this roadway. It was also noted that Kensington Terrace is used by motorists as
a bypass for Valley Street. In addition, congestion and significant pedestrian
traffic were identified at the intersection of Parker Avenue and Kensington
Terrace due to Columbia High School.
Kensington Terrace is an
undivided two-lane local
road running south to north
with an approximate
roadway width of 30 feet
and extends from Oakland
Road to Parker Avenue.
Parker Avenue in the
vicinity of Kensington
Terrace is an undivided
two-lane urban collector
running west to east with
an approximate roadway
width of 34 feet. Both
roadways have a posted
speed limit of 25 mph and
are under the jurisdiction of
Maplewood Township.
The intersection of Parker Avenue and Kensington Terrace is a ‘T’ type
intersection with Kensington Terrace forming the stem of the ‘T’. The Parker
Avenue eastbound approach consists of a through/right lane with one receiving

text.b: Traffic Calming Needs Study – Township of Maplewood, Essex County

page.text: August 2007
lane while the westbound approach consists of a left/through lane and one
receiving lane. The Kensington Terrace approach of the intersection consists of
a left/right lane with one receiving lane. The intersection is controlled by a stop
sign on the Kensington Terrace approach. The intersection is illuminated with a
single luminaire mounted on a utility pole in the northwest quadrant of the
intersection. Sidewalks currently exist along both sides of Parker Avenue and
Kensington Terrace. Crosswalks exist along all approaches. A S1-1, School
Crossing, sign with a supplemental W16-7p, Diagonal Arrow, sign is posted
along both of the Parker Avenue approaches at the intersection.
According to Maplewood Township ordinance, no vehicle shall be parked on any
thoroughfare or public parking lot between the hours of 2:00 A.M. and 6:00 A.M.
Stopping and standing is prohibited along Kensington Terrace northbound from
Crowell Place to Parker Avenue. Parking is prohibited along both sides of
Kensington Terrace between the hours of 9:00 A.M. to 11:00 A.M. and 1:00 P.M.
to 3:00 P.M. on school days unless those vehicles are owned by a resident
parking in front of their residence, a contractor, service and delivery vehicle or an
emergency vehicle as stated in the provisions of 257-18B. Parking along
Kensington Terrace is restricted to a time period of two hours between 8:00 A.M.
and 4:00 P.M. on school days from Oakland Road to Parker Avenue. Parking
along Kensington Terrace northbound is restricted to a time period of two hours
between 8:00 A.M. and 4:00 P.M. on school days from Oakland Road to Crowell
Place. Parking along Kensington Terrace southbound is restricted to a time
period of two hours between 8:00 A.M. and 4:00 P.M. on school days from
Oakland Road to Parker Avenue.
Stopping and standing is prohibited along Parker Avenue westbound from Valley
Street to Academy Street. Parking is prohibited along both sides of Parker
Avenue between the hours of 9:00 A.M. to 11:00 A.M. and 1:00 P.M. to 3:00 P.M.
on school days unless those vehicles are owned by a resident parking in front of
their residence, a contractor, service and delivery vehicle or an emergency
vehicle as stated in the provisions of 257-18B. Parking along Parker Avenue
eastbound is restricted to a time period of two hours between 8:00 A.M. and 4:00
P.M. on school days from Valley Street to Summit Avenue.
The land use in the vicinity of Parker Avenue and Kensington Terrace is basically
residential. The majority of the single-family residences within the project area
have off-street parking. Columbia High School is immediately adjacent to the
intersection of Parker Avenue and Kensington Terrace.
Traffic Analyses: Keller and Kirkpatrick, along with the Maplewood Township
Engineer’s Office, performed a classified manual turning movement count
program for the unsignalized intersections of Parker Avenue and Kensington
Terrace and Kensington Terrace and Edgewood Place on Wednesday, October
18, 2006 between the hours of 6:00 and 9:30 A.M, 11:00 A.M. and 2:00 P.M.,

text.b: Traffic Calming Needs Study – Township of Maplewood, Essex County

page.text: August 2007
and 3:00 and 6:00 P.M. The count data was classified in 15-minute increments
into the following categories:
Pedestrians
Automobiles / Light Trucks
Medium Trucks – single unit trucks
Heavy Trucks/Buses – tractor trailers
Keller and Kirkpatrick summarized the count data in a traffic flow diagram for
each intersection, which indicates the AM, midday and PM peak hour turning
volumes. A copy of the traffic flow diagram can be found in Appendix C.
Level of Service (LOS) and queue analyses using Synchro 6 were performed for
the existing conditions at the intersections of Parker Avenue and Kensington
Terrace and Kensington Terrace and Edgewood Place. The results of the
Synchro analyses are summarized in the following table:

As indicated in the analyses, all of the approaches to the intersection of Parker
Avenue and Kensington Terrace operate at a LOS ‘B’ or better during each of the

which operates at a LOS ‘C’. All of the approaches to the intersection of

text.b: Traffic Calming Needs Study – Township of Maplewood, Essex County

page.text: August 2007
Conceptual Solutions: The following summarizes two conceptual solutions
which addresses the need for traffic calming measures and/or traffic safety
improvements as identified in the traffic survey for Kensington Terrace. Input
received at the February 22, 2007 field meeting with the Maplewood Township
Engineer was incorporated, where appropriate, in the recommended
improvements.
Conceptual Solution No. 1 proposes to construct a traffic circle at the
intersection of Kensington Terrace and Edgewood Place and speed cushions
along Kensington Terrace between Parker Avenue and Crowell Place, Crowell
Place and Edgewood Place, Edgewood Place and Lincoln Place, and Lincoln
Place and Oakland Road. This would reduce speeding and deter vehicles from
using this roadway as a bypass since vehicles would be forced to slow down
along the roadway. In addition, the traffic circle would include pavers or other
treatment to create a mountable curb for larger vehicles.
The estimated construction cost for the Conceptual Solution No. 1 is $37,000,
which does not include any costs associated with right of way acquisition or utility
impacts. A copy of the construction cost estimate can be found in Appendix E.
¾ Install raised intersections at the following intersecting roadways with
Kensington Terrace.
The estimated construction cost for the Conceptual Solution No. 2 is $39,000,
which does not include any costs associated with right of way acquisition or utility
impacts. A copy of the construction cost estimate can be found in Appendix E.
In addition to Conceptual Solution Nos. 1 and 2, the following lists the
recommended improvements to the intersection of Parker Avenue and
Kensington Terrace to address the significant pedestrian volume:
¾ Install bump-outs in the southwest and southeast quadrants and along the
north side of Parker Avenue adjacent to Columbia High School. The bump-
outs will, reduce pedestrian crossing distances, increase visibility for and of
the pedestrian and may reduce travel speeds along Parker Avenue.
¾ The pedestrian crosswalks should include “ladder” striping as recommended
